On March 6, 1902, the Madrid Foot-Ball Club was officially founded under the presidency of Juan Padr√≥s. In these early years, the club began to stand out in the Regional Championship and won its first Spanish Cups. In 1920, King Alfonso XIII granted it the title of \'Real\', thus giving birth to the name we know today. It was an era of pioneers who played on pitches like O\'Donnell or the Velodrome, laying the foundations for the white ambition.
Santiago Bernab√©u becomes the club president

In 1943, Santiago Bernab√©u assumed the presidency at one of the most critical moments after the post-war period. His vision was revolutionary: he understood that to be the greatest, they needed the best setting, promoting the construction of the new stadium (opened in 1947). Bernab√©u not only rebuilt the facilities but also professionalized the institution and sowed the values of nobility and ambition that today form Real Madrid\'s DNA.
The 5 European Cups in a row.

The arrival of Alfredo Di St√©fano in 1953 marked a before and after in football history. Together with legends like Puskas, Gento, Kopa, and Santamar√≠a, Real Madrid became the dominant force on the continent. They consecutively won the first five European Cups (1956-1960), a feat never repeated. The team was admired for its attacking play and elegance, being recognized worldwide as the best team of the era.

After the retirement of the great legends, the club reinvented itself with a team made up entirely of Spanish players, known as \'The Y√©-y√©s\'. Led by veteran Paco Gento, they managed to win the Sixth European Cup in 1966 in Brussels. During the 70s, the team maintained its dominance in Spain by winning multiple leagues and cups, consolidating the club\'s mystique and the legend of players like Pirri, Amancio, or Santillana.

In the early 80s, a generation of footballers emerged from the youth system that would change the club\'s style: The Quinta del Buitre. Formed by Butrague√±o, M√≠chel, Sanch√≠s, Mart√≠n V√°zquez, and Pardeza, this team made the Bernab√©u fall in love with its technical and associative football. They achieved the milestone of winning five consecutive Leagues (1986-1990) and two UEFA Cups, marking a decade of total football in Spain, although the European Cup cruelly resisted them.
From the Seventh to the Ninth

The 90s brought the long-awaited return to European glory. In 1998, Real Madrid won \'The Seventh\' in Amsterdam thanks to Pedja Mijatovic\'s unforgettable goal, breaking a 32-year drought. It was the start of a new golden era where the Eighth (2000) in the first-ever all-Spanish final, and the Ninth (2002) with Zidane\'s masterful volley in Glasgow during the Centenary year, would soon arrive.

With the turn of the new millennium, Florentino P√©rez promoted a model based on gathering the best players on the planet. The club signed stars like Figo, Zidane, Ronaldo, and Beckham, creating the team known as \'The Galacticos\'. Beyond the titles, the club experienced unprecedented global expansion and was recognized by FIFA as the Best Club of the 20th Century, elevating the Real Madrid brand to a worldwide level.
The Portuguese star arrives at the Castellana.

In 2009, one of the most successful cycles in modern history began. Cristiano Ronaldo arrived at the club to become its all-time top scorer. Under the direction of coaches like Mourinho, Ancelotti, and Zidane, the historical milestone of winning four Champions Leagues in five years was achieved, including three of them consecutively (2016-2018). It was the era of \'The Tenth\', impossible comebacks, and absolute European dominance.

Current Real Madrid faces the future with the remodeling of the Santiago Bernab√©u, destined to be the best stadium in the world. Sportingly, the club has managed an exemplary transition by joining legendary veterans like Modric or Kroos with young stars like Vin√≠cius Jr, Bellingham, or Rodrygo. In 2022, the 14th Champions was achieved with one of the most epic editions remembered, and in 2024, the 15th, confirming that the club\'s ambition knows no limits.

All-time top scorer in Real Madrid history. Winner of 4 Champions Leagues and 4 Ballon d\'Ors with the club.

Cristiano Ronaldo (Madeira, 1985) is the all-time top scorer in Real Madrid history with 451 goals in 438 matches. He arrived in 2009 and marked a golden era, leading the team to win 4 Champions Leagues, 3 of them consecutively. His ambition, physical power, and scoring ability make him one of the best players of all time.
The current Brazilian star. Scorer of the goal for the 14th and key figure in the 15th. Dribbling and joy.
He is very fast and dances.

Vin√≠cius Jos√© Paix√£o de Oliveira J√∫nior (S√£o Gon√ßalo, 2000) arrived at Real Madrid at 18 years old. His evolution has been meteoric, going from a promise to a world reality. He scored the decisive goal in the 2022 Champions League final against Liverpool. His speed, dribbling, and charisma have made him the idol of the new madridista generation.
2018 Ballon d\'Or. The brain of the team and an example of longevity and world class.

Luka Modriƒá (Zadar, 1985) is the engine of Real Madrid. He arrived in 2012 and became a fundamental piece of the 6 Champions Leagues won in a decade. In 2018 he broke the hegemony of Messi and Cristiano by winning the Ballon d\'Or. His vision of the game, control, and passes with the outside of his boot are world football heritage.
The German legend. The metronome who directed Madrid\'s game during a glorious decade.

Toni Kroos (Greifswald, 1990) defined the rhythm of Real Madrid from his arrival in 2014 until his retirement in 2024. With almost perfect passing precision, he formed one of the best midfields in history alongside Modric and Casemiro. He won 5 Champions Leagues with the club and retired at the top, being cheered by the entire Bernab√©u.
The best goalkeeper in the history of Real Madrid and Spanish football. Eternal captain.

Iker Casillas (M√≥stoles, 1981) is a madridista myth. He spent almost his entire career at the club, defending the goal for 16 seasons in the first team. His miraculous saves earned him the nickname \'The Saint\'. He captained the team in winning the Tenth and lifted countless titles, being a symbol of the youth academy.
2022 Ballon d\'Or. Second all-time top scorer and a 9 with the soul of a 10.
He plays with a lot of class.

Karim Benzema (Lyon, 1987) starred in one of the greatest evolutions in the club\'s history. For years he was Cristiano\'s perfect partner, but after his departure, he assumed the scoring leadership. His 2021-2022 season was historic, with hat-tricks and epic comebacks that earned him the Ballon d\'Or. He left as the player with the most titles alongside Marcelo (25).
